reasoning: The query asks about periods within the last 10,000 years when the planet was significantly warmer than today. The existing results are weak because they either focus on events far outside this time frame (e.g., PETM) or are only tangentially related to the core concept of sustained warmth within the specified timeframe (e.g., January thaw, marine regression). To address this, I need to focus the query on the Holocene epoch (the last 11,700 years) and look for specific warm periods or events within it. Goal: Find evidence of sustained warmer periods within the Holocene.
query_goals: Identify specific periods of warmth within the last 10,000 years (Holocene).
Determine the magnitude of warming relative to present-day temperatures during those periods.
Find evidence about the duration of these warmer periods.
Explore potential causes or drivers of these Holocene warm periods.
Distinguish between regional and global warming events.
augmented_query: "Holocene Climate Optimum OR Medieval Warm Period OR Roman Warm Period OR Bronze Age climate -Little Ice Age AND (temperature anomaly OR warmer than present OR increased temperatures) AND (past 10000 years OR Holocene) AND (solar variability OR volcanic eruptions OR orbital forcing)"
query: Also, it is increasingly clear that the planet was significantly warmer than today several times during the past 10,000 years.
cleaned_augmented_query: holocene climate optimum medieval warm period roman warm period bronze age climate little ice age temperature anomaly warmer present increased temperatures past 10000 years holocene solar variability volcanic eruptions orbital forcing
initial_results:
### Text snippet from document at k=1
... The period is marked by a prominent negative excursion in carbon stable isotope records from around the globe ; more specifically , there was a large decrease in 13C/12C ratio of marine and terrestrial carbonates and organic carbon .   Stratigraphic sections of rock from this period reveal numerous other changes . Fossil records for many organisms show major turnovers . For example , in the marine realm , a mass extinction of benthic foraminifera , a global expansion of subtropical dinoflagellates , and an appearance of excursion , planktic foraminifera and calcareous nanofossils all occurred during the beginning stages of PETM . On land , modern mammal orders ( including primates ) suddenly appear in Europe and in North America . Sediment deposition changed significantly at many outcrops and in many drill cores spanning this time interval .   At least since 1997 , the Paleocene -- Eocene Thermal Maximum has become a focal point of considerable geoscience research because it probably provides the best past analog by which to understand impacts of global climate warming and of massive carbon input to the ocean and atmosphere , including ocean acidification . Although it is now widely accepted that the PETM represents a `` case study '' for global warming and massive carbon input to Earth 's surface , the cause , details and overall significance of the event remain perplexing .

### Text snippet from document at k=2
: Termination , as used by Quaternary geologists , oceanographers , and paleoclimatologists is the period of time during an glacial cycle when there is a relatively rapid transition from full glacial climates to full interglacial climates . For the Quaternary period , terminations are numbered using Roman numerals from the most recent termination as `` I '' and with increasing value , e.g. `` II '' , `` III '' , and so forth , into the past . Termination I , also known as the Last Glacial Termination , is the end of Marine isotope stage 2 ; Termination II is the end of Marine Isotope Stage 6 ; Termination III is the end of Marine Isotope Stage 8 ; Termination IV is the end of Marine Isotope Stage 10 , and so forth .   During the Quaternary , global climate experienced a recurring pattern of ice-sheet growth and decay . The length of Late Quaternary cycles varied between 80,000 and 120,000 years , with an average recurrence interval of about 100,000 years . ...

### Text snippet from document at k=10
... These periods are caused by variations in eccentricity , axial tilt , and precession of the Earth 's orbit . As part of the ongoing supercontinent cycle , plate tectonics will probably result in a supercontinent in 250 -- 350 million years . Some time in the next 1.5 -- 4.5 billion years , the axial tilt of the Earth may begin to undergo chaotic variations , with changes in the axial tilt of up to 90 ° .   During the next four billion years , the luminosity of the Sun will steadily increase , resulting in a rise in the solar radiation reaching the Earth . This will result in a higher rate of weathering of silicate minerals , which will cause a decrease in the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere . In about 600 million years from now , the level of CO2 will fall below the level needed to sustain C3 carbon fixation photosynthesis used by trees . Some plants use the C4 carbon fixation method , allowing them to persist at concentrations as low as 10 parts per million . However , the long-term trend is for plant life to die off altogether . The extinction of plants will be the demise of almost all animal life , since plants are the base of the food chain on Earth .   In about one billion years , the solar luminosity will be 10 % higher than at present . ...
thought_process:
Looking at the original query, "Also, it is increasingly clear that the planet was significantly warmer than today several times during the past 10,000 years," this makes me think of various geological and climatic events that could have contributed to such periods of warmth. Though the user might actually be trying to understand the implications of these warm periods on current climate change discussions, I'm not sure yet how deeply they want to dive into the scientific aspects. 

Analyzing the results of the original query, I notice that the retrieved documents often focus on events outside the specified 10,000-year timeframe or only tangentially relate to sustained warmth within this period. For instance, the first document snippet discusses the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), which, although relevant to global warming discussions, falls outside our time frame of interest. The second snippet talks about terminations in glacial cycles, which could be relevant but doesn't directly address warmth within the last 10,000 years. The tenth snippet jumps far into the future, discussing long-term changes in Earth's climate due to solar luminosity increases and their impact on plant life, which, while intriguing, doesn't directly pertain to our query about past warm periods.

To approach this query expansion systematically, I'll use the Conceptual Graph Traversal technique. This involves constructing a conceptual graph with core nodes representing the main entities and concepts from the query, first-order connections for direct properties and relationships, second-order connections for related concepts, and domain contexts for specialized fields relevant to the query.

First, I identify the core concepts: "warm periods," "past 10,000 years," and "global temperatures." The search intent is informational, aiming to understand historical climate patterns. An implicit assumption is that these warm periods are significant enough to be notable in scientific literature.

Constructing the graph, core nodes include "Holocene," "climate optimum," "Medieval Warm Period," and "Roman Warm Period." First-order connections involve relationships like "caused by" (e.g., solar variability, volcanic eruptions) and "characterized by" (e.g., temperature anomalies, sea-level changes). Second-order connections might include related concepts such as "Little Ice Age" for contrast or "Bond events" and "Dansgaard-Oeschger events" for additional climatic fluctuations within the Holocene.

For expansion path selection, promising directions include synonymous terms (e.g., "thermal maximum" for "warm period"), hierarchical terms (e.g., "Holocene Climate Optimum" as a specific warm period), compositional terms (e.g., "solar radiation" as a component influencing climate), contextual terms (e.g., "marine ecosystems" as a setting affected by warmth), and domain-specific terminology (e.g., "paleoclimatology" as the field studying ancient climates).

Extracting and filtering terms, I look for relevance, distinctiveness, specificity, and searchability. High-value terms might include "Holocene Climate Optimum," "Medieval Warm Period," "Roman Warm Period," "temperature anomaly," "past 10,000 years," "Holocene," "solar variability," "volcanic eruptions," and "orbital forcing." These terms balance specificity with broad relevance to the query's core concepts.

Through this process of applying Conceptual Graph Traversal and exploring related threads, I believe the selected terms would be most effective for enhancing the query. They capture both the explicit (e.g., "Holocene") and implicit (e.g., the search for instances of significant warmth) aspects of what the user is seeking. The augmented query, "Holocene Climate Optimum OR Medieval Warm Period OR Roman Warm Period OR Bronze Age climate -Little Ice Age AND (temperature anomaly OR warmer than present OR increased temperatures) AND (past 10000 years OR Holocene) AND (solar variability OR volcanic eruptions OR orbital forcing)," reflects a structured approach to uncovering relevant information about past warm periods within the specified timeframe, complemented by intuitive connections to broader climatic concepts and events.
